user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_GetOpText:
```c
const char *UtAssert_GetOpText(UtAssert_Compare_t CompareType)
{
    const char *OpText;

    switch (CompareType)
    {
        case UtAssert_Compare_EQ: /* actual equals reference value */
            OpText = "==";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_NEQ: /* actual does not non equal reference value */
            OpText = "!=";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_LT: /* actual less than reference (exclusive) */
            OpText = "<";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_GT: /* actual greater than reference (exclusive)  */
            OpText = ">";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_LTEQ: /* actual less than or equal to reference (inclusive) */
            OpText = "<=";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_GTEQ: /* actual greater than reference (inclusive) */
            OpText = ">=";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_BITMASK_SET: /* bit(s) in reference are set in actual */
            OpText = "&";
            break;
        case UtAssert_Compare_BITMASK_UNSET: /* bit(s) in reference are not set in actual */
            OpText = "&~";
            break;
        default: /* should never happen */
            OpText = "??";
            break;
    }

    return OpText;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. The fragment contains only standard C constructs: a function returning const char *, a local pointer variable, a switch statement on an (assumed) enum type UtAssert_Compare_t, standard case labels including a default, string literals, comments, and break statements. There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm/__asm__, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, designated initializers with nonstandard syntax, inline assembly, compiler-specific keywords (e.g. __extension__, __builtin_*, __declspec), nonstandard pragmas, or other documented vendor extensions. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
